t: A Lament for the Princes of Israel
And*p you, take up a lamentation for the princes of Israel,
and say: What*pn was your mother? A lioness! Among*ld lions she crouched; in*ln the midst of young lions she*ld reared her cubs.
And*ln she brought up one of her cubs; he*ld became a young lion, and*ln he learned to catch prey; he*ld devoured men.
The*ln nations heard about him; he*ld was caught in their pit, and*ln they brought him with hooks to*ld the land of Egypt.
When*ln she saw that she waited in vain, that*ld her hope was lost, she*ln took another of her cubs and*ld made him a young lion.
He*ln prowled among the lions; he*ld became a young lion, and*ln he learned to catch prey; he*ld devoured men,
and*ln seized their widows. He*ld laid waste their cities, and*ln the land was appalled and all who were in it at*ld the sound of his roaring.
Then*ln the nations set against him from*ld provinces on every side; they*ln spread their net over him; he*ld was taken in their pit.
With*ln hooks they put him in a cage and*ld brought him to the king of Babylon; they*ld brought him into custody, that*ln his voice should no more be heard on*ld the mountains of Israel.
Your*pn mother was like a vine in a vineyard planted*ld by the water, fruitful*ln and full of branches by*ld reason of abundant water.
Its*ln strong stems became rulersâ€™*ld scepters; it*ln towered aloft among*ld the thick boughs; it*ln was seen in its height with*ld the mass of its branches.
But*ln the vine was plucked up in fury, cast*ld down to the ground; the*ln east wind dried up its fruit; they*ld were stripped off and withered. As*ln for its strong stem, fire*ld consumed it.
Now*ln it is planted in the wilderness, in*ld a dry and thirsty land.

And*ln fire has gone out from the stem of its shoots, has*ld consumed its fruit, so*ln that there remains in it no strong stem, no*ld scepter for ruling. This*p is a lamentation and has become a lamentation.
